text: Ceratozamia morettii is a species of plant in the family Zamiaceae. It is endemic to Mexico, where it is limited to the state of Veracruz north of Jalapa. It grows on steep clay and basalt cliffs in cloud forest habitat.Vovides, A. & Chemnick, J. 2010. Ceratozamia morettii. The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2015.2. Downloaded on 05 September 2015. This cycad is palm-like in appearance but with a trunk no more than 30 centimeters long, often shorter, and quite variable in shape. It has up to 10 leaves which are up to 140 centimeters long by 65 wide and are made up of 12 to 25 pairs of leaflets.Vázquez-Torres, M., & Vovides, A. P. (1998). A new species of Ceratozamia (Zamiaceae) from Veracruz, Mexico. Novon 87-90. Other native plants in this species' nearly inaccessible cloud forest habitat include Alnus jorullensis, Clethra mexicana, Dendropanax arboreus, Dicksonia gigantea, Ilex discolor, Liquidambar macrophylla, Magnolia schiedeana, Marattia laxa, Oreopanax capitatus, Ostrya virginiana, and Podocarpus guatemalensis. ==References== morettii Category:Endemic flora of Mexico Category:Flora of Veracruz Category:Endangered plants Category:Endangered biota of Mexico Category:Plants described in 1998 Category:Taxonomy articles created by Polbot
title: Ceratozamia morettii
